paper_title: Photocatalytic reduction of CO2 into CO over nanostructure Bi2S3 quantum dots/g-C3N4 composites with Z-scheme mechanism

catalyst.source: Photocatalytic reduction of CO2 into CO over nanostructure Bi2S3 quantum dots/g-C3N4 composites with Z-scheme mechanism
catalyst.context: Photocatalytic reduction of CO2 into CO over nanostructure Bi2S3 quantum dots/g-C3N4 composites with Z-scheme mechanism

catalyst.source: Bi 2 S 3 quantum dots (QDs) /g-C 3 N 4 composites with various Bi 2 S 3 QDs contents were synthesized by hydrothermal reaction method and used in CO 2 photocatalytic reduction, which demonstrated much higher photocatalytic activity than pristine g-C 3 N 4 .
catalyst.context: Bi 2 S 3 quantum dots (QDs) /g-C 3 N 4 composites with various Bi 2 S 3 QDs contents were synthesized by hydrothermal reaction method and used in CO 2 photocatalytic reduction, which demonstrated much higher photocatalytic activity than pristine g-C 3 N 4 .Experimental results indicated that the 20 wt Bi 2 S 3 QDs/g-C 3 N 4 showed a remarkable photocatalytic activity, which was 4 times the CO yield of that pure g-C 3 N 4 .The SEM and TEM results indicated that Bi 2 S 3 QDs had uniformly covered the catalysts surface, which could effectively increase the absorption of visible-light and promote the separation of photogenerated carriers, thereby decrease the recombination rate of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and enhance the performance of photocatalytic reduction.

catalyst.source: Suitable urea was heated in air at 520 C for 4 h to obtain pure g-C 3 N 4 .
catalyst.context: Urea (H 2 NCONH 3 ), acetone (CH 3 COCH 3 ), sodium thiosulfate pentahydrate (Na 2 S 2 O 3 5H 2 O) and bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi (NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Corp, P. R. China.All reagents are of analytical grade and applied without any further purification. Suitable urea was heated in air at 520 C for 4 h to obtain pure g-C 3 N 4 .The Bi 2 S 3 QDs/g-C 3 N 4 composites with different Bi 2 S 3 QDs mass ratio (0, 10, 20 and 30 wt) were obtained by the following steps: 0.081 g (0.167 mmol) Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O was dissolved in 35 mL acetone with intense stirring for 30 min, then a certain amount (0.429, 0.215 and 0.143 g, 4.66, 2.34 and 1.55 mmol) of g-C 3 N 4 and Na 2 S 2 O 3 5H 2 O (0.062 g, 0.25 mmol) were mixed in the prepared solution and vigorously stirred for 30 min to obtain a uniform solution.The obtained mixture solution was then hydrothermally treated in a 100 mL Teflonlined autoclave at 180 C for 24 h.The resulted product was washed with absolute ethanol and deionized water for several times, then dried at 80 C overnight.Pure Bi 2 S 3 QDs was synthesized by the identical method without the existence of g-C 3 N 4 . The crystal phase of the catalysts were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement (Bruker D8 Advance powder diffractometer, CuK radiation, 0.154056 nm).The morphology of photocatalysts were observed by the scanning electron microscope (SEM, Phillips XL-30 FEG/NEW) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, Phillips Model CM200).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250xi, USA) with Al K radiation sources were used to validate the compositions of the chemical elements.The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore structure were estimated by N 2 adsorption-desorption at -196 C on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-AG instrument.For the analysis of optical absorption properties, BaSO 4 was used as a reflection standard material, and a UV-vis diffuse reflection spectrum was recorded on a spectrophotometer (SHIMADZU UV-3600, Japan) in the range of 250-800 nm.Reduction of CO 2 was characterized by attenuated total internal reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR, Nicolet iS50).Photoluminescence (PL) characteristics were analyzed by a 325 nm excitation wavelength fluorescence spectrophotometer (Hitachi F-4600). Photoelectrochemical measurements including electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and transient photocurrent responses analysis were measured on an electrochemical system (CHI 660E, Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co., Ltd.China).A typical three-electrode was immersed in a 0.5 mol/L Na 2 SO 4 electrolyte solution.Fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) conductive glass covered by the prepared sample was employed as the working electrode, while Pt and Ag/AgCl electrodes were employed as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively.The working electrode was obtained by the following steps: the prepared sample (10 mg) was dispersed into a mixed solution of ethanol (1 mL) and nafion (20 L, 5), then the mixture was ultrasonically dispersed for 2 h.After that, 0.1 mL slurry was dropped on the surface of FTO glass (1 1 cm).After evaporation of ethanol, the photocatalyst was uniformly attached to the FTO glass.EIS and photocurrent measurements were taken with a 300 W Xenon lamp. A typical photocatalytic CO 2 reduction experiment was conducted in a gas-enclosed circulation system with a 500 mL reactor purchased from Perfect Light Company (Beijing, China).A 300 W Xenon arc lamp was used as the light source during the operation.In a standard experimental procedure, 50 mg photocatalyst was mixed with 100 mL deionized water under appropriate magnetic stirring to achieve the uniform dispersion.Before light irradiation, the suspension was firstly subjected to a vacuum treatment, then pure CO 2 (99.999) was introduced into the reaction vessel under the control of a mass flow meter, and the pressure were maintained at 100 kPa for 30 min to achieve the balance of adsorption-desorption.The temperature was controlled at 25C during the entire experiment.During the reaction process, 0.15 mL of gas was collected from the glass chamber every hour, and the carbon-based evaporation product was specifically identified by a gas chromatography (GC-2010 Plus, SHIMADZU, Japan).

Photoelectrochemical measurements including electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and transient photocurrent responses analysis were measured on an electrochemical system (CHI 660E, Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co., Ltd.China).A typical three-electrode was immersed in a 0.5 mol/L Na 2 SO 4 electrolyte solution.Fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) conductive glass covered by the prepared sample was employed as the working electrode, while Pt and Ag/AgCl electrodes were employed as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively.The working electrode was obtained by the following steps: the prepared sample (10 mg) was dispersed into a mixed solution of ethanol (1 mL) and nafion (20 L, 5), then the mixture was ultrasonically dispersed for 2 h.After that, 0.1 mL slurry was dropped on the surface of FTO glass (1 1 cm).After evaporation of ethanol, the photocatalyst was uniformly attached to the FTO glass.EIS and photocurrent measurements were taken with a 300 W Xenon lamp. A typical photocatalytic CO 2 reduction experiment was conducted in a gas-enclosed circulation system with a 500 mL reactor purchased from Perfect Light Company (Beijing, China).A 300 W Xenon arc lamp was used as the light source during the operation.In a standard experimental procedure, 50 mg photocatalyst was mixed with 100 mL deionized water under appropriate magnetic stirring to achieve the uniform dispersion.Before light irradiation, the suspension was firstly subjected to a vacuum treatment, then pure CO 2 (99.999) was introduced into the reaction vessel under the control of a mass flow meter, and the pressure were maintained at 100 kPa for 30 min to achieve the balance of adsorption-desorption.The temperature was controlled at 25C during the entire experiment.During the reaction process, 0.15 mL of gas was collected from the glass chamber every hour, and the carbon-based evaporation product was specifically identified by a gas chromatography (GC-2010 Plus, SHIMADZU, Japan).
